articles.headline: To Buff a Balkan Leader’s Image, a Filmmaker Calls In Kevin Spacey
articles.snippet: A director cast the beleaguered actor as Franjo Tudjman, the late Croatian leader, whom some call a patriot and others revile as an ethnonationalist zealot.
articles.abstract: A director cast the beleaguered actor as Franjo Tudjman, the late Croatian leader, whom some call a patriot and others revile as an ethnonationalist zealot.
articles.lead_paragraph: A hagiographic movie about the stiff former leader of a small Balkan country was never going to be a global box-office hit. But its director, a former water polo champion turned darling of right-wing Croatian cinema, found a novel way to generate some buzz: He cast Kevin Spacey as its star.

articles.headline: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
articles.snippet: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
articles.abstract: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one of their deadliest attacks yet on Russian forces, Ukrainians used American-made rockets to kill dozens — and perhaps hundreds — of Moscow’s troops in a New Year’s Day strike behind the lines, prompting outraged Russian war hawks to accuse their military of lethal incompetence.
articles.byline: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
articles.snippet: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
articles.abstract: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIHAIL KOGALNICEANU AIR BASE, Romania — The soldiers of the U.S. Army’s 101st Airborne Division train, eat and sleep on a drab, sprawling post in southeast Romania, a mere seven-minute rocket flight from where Russia has stockpiled munitions in Crimea.

articles.headline: Wave of Job-Switching Has Employers on a Training Treadmill
articles.snippet: The rise in turnover since the pandemic started has a cost in productivity: “It’s taking longer to get stuff out the door.”
articles.abstract: The rise in turnover since the pandemic started has a cost in productivity: “It’s taking longer to get stuff out the door.”
articles.lead_paragraph: One after another, employees at the New Hampshire manufacturer W.H. Bagshaw said goodbye.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: House G.O.P. Paralyzed on Day 1 as Right Wing Blocks McCarthy Speakership
articles.snippet: On the first day of the new Congress, Representative Kevin McCarthy fell short repeatedly in his bid to become speaker as a right-wing rebellion prompted a historic floor fight.
articles.abstract: On the first day of the new Congress, Representative Kevin McCarthy fell short repeatedly in his bid to become speaker as a right-wing rebellion prompted a historic floor fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans were deadlocked on Tuesday over who would lead their new majority after Representative Kevin McCarthy of California lost three votes for the top job, as hard-right lawmakers in open revolt dealt their party leader a humiliating setback and prompted a historic struggle on the House floor.

articles.headline: Why Japan’s Sudden Shift on Bond Purchases Dealt a Global Jolt
articles.snippet: The world has relied on ultralow interest rates in Japan. What will happen if they rise?
articles.abstract: The world has relied on ultralow interest rates in Japan. What will happen if they rise?
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan is the world’s largest creditor. At the end of 2021, it held roughly $3.2 trillion in foreign assets, 30 percent more than No. 2 Germany. As of October, it owned over a trillion dollars of U.S. government debt, more than China. Japanese banks are the world’s largest cross-border lenders, with nearly $4.8 trillion in claims in other countries.

articles.headline: Is a Dam in Rural Portugal a Key to Our Alternative Energy Future?
articles.snippet: When the Portuguese electric power grid needs more electricity, a large multinational power company releases millions of gallons of water from a dammed reservoir.
articles.abstract: When the Portuguese electric power grid needs more electricity, a large multinational power company releases millions of gallons of water from a dammed reservoir.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Portugal’s electrical system needs a boost, a signal activates a power plant buried deep in a hillside in the country’s scrubby, pine-covered north. Inside the man-made cavern, valves, nine feet in diameter, suddenly open, allowing water draining from a reservoir four miles away to begin streaming through four massive turbines.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Matilde Viegas

articles.headline: Japan’s Business Owners Can’t Find Successors. This Man Is Giving His Away.
articles.snippet: An owner’s struggle in Japan’s northern dairy region illuminates one of the potentially devastating economic impacts of an aging society.
articles.abstract: An owner’s struggle in Japan’s northern dairy region illuminates one of the potentially devastating economic impacts of an aging society.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hidekazu Yokoyama has spent three decades building a thriving logistics business on Japan’s snowy northern island of Hokkaido, an area that provides much of the country’s milk.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: In a Hospital Ward, the Wounds of a Failed Democracy Don’t Heal
articles.snippet: Tunisia’s road to democracy began with a self-immolation, and such cases have filled hospital burn wards ever since, as elected leaders failed to deliver on a promise of prosperity.
articles.abstract: Tunisia’s road to democracy began with a self-immolation, and such cases have filled hospital burn wards ever since, as elected leaders failed to deliver on a promise of prosperity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most troublesome patient in the hospital’s severe burns unit was refusing to let the orderlies change the bandages that had encased him since he set himself on fire three months earlier, so Dr. Imen Jami burst into his room, her habitually knit brows drawn as tight as they would go, her lips pressed together in a magenta line.
